f 304 (8 November) (Cupboard order)
. . .
Eightly for that the disorders in the Christmas tyme may booth infecte
the mynds and preiudice the estats & fortunes of the younger gentlemen
in the same Societies It is Therfore Ordered that ther shalbe commons
off the howse kept in every howse of Court duringe the Crismas and that
none shall play in the severall halls at the dice except he be a gentleman of
the sam Societie & in Commons & the benefitt of the boxes to goo to the
Butlers of every howse Respectively.

Lincoln's Inn Black Book 6 LI Arch: A1a6
f 558v (24 November) (Council orders)
. . .
Mr Thomas Hitchcocke & Mr Christopher Brooke are to conferre with
two of the Masters of the Bench of the Temples touchinge the charge of
the late Maske at the Lady Elizabeths marriadge for the satisfaccion of
such moneyes as are yet arrere, & behind vnpaid for that this Howsse hath
made theire accounte and sent it to the Temple, but they haue made noe
accompte, nor haue sent any to this Howsse. And Mr Christopher Brooke
is to haue the iiij Maskinge suites to paye himselfe, & to accoumpte for the
reste to this howsse./

Inner Temple Parliament Book LT Arch: PAR1112
f 120v* (21 April)
. . .
Whereas George Low cheife Cooke of this house hath exhibited his peticion
to this Bench shewing the great Charg which he hath bene and is to be
att about the repairing of a litle Chamber or roome which he had in the
Cloister by reason the same or a great parte thereof and the Chimney therein
was att Christmas was a twelvemonth broken downe by such as climed vpp

10/ Revevells: for Revells
37–8/ the Cloister: connecting the Temple Church to Inner Temple Hall

att the windows of the hall to see the maske which then was, therevpon
Desiering some estate in the same room or Chamber towards his said chardge
It is ordered vpon this his suite in respect of his said Cost and Chardge that
he may have liberty to nominate vnto Master Threasourer some one of ye
fellowes of this house to be admitted into ye same and the benefitt of such
reasonable composition as he shall make for the same by ye allowance of ye
Threasourer of the house for ye time being is granted to him and the house
to have no other benefitt by the said admittance for this time But onely the
ordinary dutie of the admittance and the said Cheife Cooke to have the
rest to his owne vse.

commons desireth an allowance of x li., which was layd vppon him by the

is generallye disliked by all the bench nowe present that any such demand

should be made, or any such charge layde on the house without movinge them

on whom yt may be layde, and for that the butler is vnable to beare the charge
thereof, Therefore for this tyme they are contented to giue allowance
thereof and that master Treasuror shall paye it with a full resolucion not to
allowe the like hereafter/

Grays Inn Pension Book GI Arch: PEN1111
f 314* (17 October) (Pension orders)
At this Pencion every Reador Ancient Barrister and other gentleman that
shalbe in the Towne betwene this and the end of Hillary terme or have any
Chamber in the howse other of the house or by lease ortherwyse shal pay
towards the Barriors intended to be presented before his Maiesti shall pay
affter these Rats and proporcions followinge Every Reador or Ancient of
the Bench xl s. every Ancient vnder the Bench xxx S. Every Barrister xx S. &
Every other gentlemen xiij s. iiij d.
[Ther is apointed for]
Mr Newton is appointed Collector of the Readors & Ancients
Mr Griffeth [for] of the Barristers
And Mr wrightington of the yonge gentlemen vnder the Barr
. . .
f 314v (8 November)
. . .
At this Pencion it is Ordered that all such gentlemen of this Societie as are
be hinde with ther taxacion towardes the barriers performed at the Courte
yf they be in Commons they shall pay ther taxacion before fryday dinnor
or els to put fourth of Commons, and that such as are forth of Commons
shal pay ther taxacion before the next Pencion in the next weeke and those
which shall not paye the same before the next pencion in the next weeke if
they have howse Chambers or Chambers by lease in the howse shall forfet
ther Chambers and if they have no Chambers then they shalbe forth of
the howse
. . .

17/ ortherwyse: for otherwyse
38/ shalbe forth: for shalbe put forth

such gentlemen
to appere before
the Bench in
the hall, as pay
not their taxe
to the Barriors.

Admittances
this Terme for
the Barriors.

31. 6S. 5d.
per Annum
allow to Michell
the Musitian
per vitam.

f 315 (18 November)
. . .
It is Ordered at this Pencion that 12 of the Ancientest Comonors that ar
behind with ther taxacion towards the barriors shall appeare before the
Readors at the tables end to morrowe at Dinnor to shewe Cause why they
pay it not and yf they do not pay nor shall give satisfaction why they doe it
not, That they shall stand expelled fourth of this Societie And so all the rest
of the Ancient Barristers and other gentlemen to appeare by 12 a day every
day affter the other till they have all appeared and be in the same Case
. . .
(21 [anuary)
At this Pencion it is Ordered that all the moneys that shalbe Receired this
terme for admissions shalbe paid and deliuered to Sir Thomas Tildesley to
be Imployed towardes the satisfaction of such as have Lent moneyes towards
the performance of the Barriors
. . .
f 315v (21 May)
. . .
At this Pencion it is Ordered that the moneys this terme Receired for
admittances shall goe and be imployed towards the payment of the Readors
of such moneys as they have lent for the settinge forth of Barriors which
is yet behinde
It is Ordered at this Pencion that Mr Michell the Musition of the howse
shall have allowed vnto him duringe his liffe five Markes to be paid every
midsomer terme out of the first admittance money that shalbe that
terme received
...

Inner Temple Parliament Book IT Arch: PAR1112
f 133 (6 November)
. . .
Wheras fforty of the Gentlemen of the Innes of Court (wherof Ten of this
Society were appoynted to be Barryers at the Court the ffowrth of this
instant November in honor of the Creation of Charles Prince of wales
which they have performed accordingly fforasmuch as the Chardge therof
being great is to be defrayed by the generall taxacion of this house: It is
nowe at this parliament ordered That euery Bencher of this house shall
35–6/ (wherof... Society: closing parenthesis omitted

paye towardes the same chardge xxx S., euery vtter Barrester above Seaven
yeres standing of the Barr shall paye xx S. and euery vtter Barrester vnder
7. yeres standing of the Barr XVS. And all other the Gentlemen of this
house which have beene in Commons in this house within one yere or shall
come into Commons within halfe a yeare, or have any Chambers within
this house shall paye XS. a peece. And further That all such as houlde any
Offices within this house shall paye a Third parte of the somme they were
Chardged with or their saide offices towardes the late maske performed by
the Gentlemen of this house together with the Gentlemen of Grayes Inne
after the marriadge of the Ladie Elizabeth the kinges Maiesties daughter
Provided always That the Gentlemen that performed the saide Barryers be
not Chardged by this Act.
...

Lincoln's Inn Black Book 6 LI Arch: A1a6
f 626v (II October) (Council orders)
. . .
It is desyred that Master Attorney Mr Hitchcocke Mr Brooke and Mr lones
would giue a meetinge with the benchers of the other three houses tlwloe
40/ giue: for haue

morrowe in the afternoone at the rolls to conferre touchinge the Barryers at
the creation of the prince as ys desyred7
...
(12 October)
Mr Christopher Brooke mr William lones two of the masters of the bench
mr William Hackwell Mr Iohn Harrison Mr Edward Oldsworth of the barre
and Mr Anthony Page and Mr Thomas Shepherd vnder the barre are at this
councell appoynted to be agentes for this house touchinge the barryers and
such other things as shalbe necessarie for that service
f 628* (15 October)
Mr Ayliffe and Mr Pyne of the Bench [mr sanderson], mr Saunderson and
Mr Chambers of the barre, Mr Lentall and Mr Rigby vnder the barre to
attend the Oueenes Councell with others of the Innes of Courte touchinge
the Convertinge of the Cocke pytte in the Feildes into a playe house
.. .
f 620v (22 October)
. . .
It is agreed that there shalbe a taxacion towards the performance of the
barryers at the princes creacion of everie Bencher an associatte at xl s. a peece,
everie barrester of Seaven yeares and aboue at xxx S., and everye barrester
vnder Seaven yeares at xx S. and of everye gentleman xiij s. iiij d., And Mr
Ayliffe one of the Masters of the bench ys desyred to be Collector of the money
to be paid by the Benchers and associates wbich is to be brought to him in the
Hall when he shall appoynt a tyme, And Mr Chambers and Mr Taylor two
vtterbarristers are appoynted collectors of the barristers of this house, And Mr
Lentall and Mr Rigbye two of the fellowes of this house vnder the barre are
appoynted Collectors of the money to be collected of the gentlemen vnder the
barre/ The colleccion to be made and the moneys to be brought in by the
collectors into the Hall by Mondaye at dynner tyme, to be paid to such as
then shalbe appoynted to receaue yt/
f 634* (12 November)
fforasmuch as Mr Richard Tufton one of the gentlemen of this house refuseth

1/ the rolls: Rolls House, Chancery Lane
23/ an associatte: ie, who is an associate
24/ Seaven yeares and aboue: ie, who has served at least seven years since his call to the bar
33/ Mondaye: 28 October 1616

to perform the order made the ffifte daye of November last past, It is therefore
ordered that the parte of the chamber which he had in this house shalbe
disposed to the vse of the house, and that mr Noye one of the vtter barristers
of this house that was his Chamberfellowe in regard of his practice shall haue
the chamber wholye to himself payinge xxx li. to the house forthwith, whereof
x li. ys to be allowed him, which he hath heretofore lent to the house towardes
the maske, vppon payment whereof and sighte of this order he may take an
admittance accordinglye from master Tresorer*
. . .
f 635* (15 November)
. . .
At this Councell vppon hearinge of mr Wyndham, It is ordered that he
shall restore ffiue poundes lent him towardes such provision he desyred to
make for himself at the barryers when he refused that was provided for
him by the house at the first councell the next tearme, if he make default
thereof then further consideracion to be had of him and his demeanori
towardes the house, and behavior towardes the bench before and at the tyme
of the said money lent
. ..
f 637v (26 November)
. . .
At this Councell vppon hearinge of mr Skinner yt is ordered that he shall
restore V li. lent him towardes such prouision he desyred to make for himself
at the barryers when he refused that was prouided for him by the house at
the first Councell the next tearme, yf he make default thereof then further
Consideracion to be had of him and his demeanor towardes the house
. . .
f 638* (28 November)
. . .
fforasmuch as the havinge of a liuetenant in the Chrismas tyme ys not
accordinge to the Auncyant orders and vsages of the house, And ys found
to be inconvenient and verye chargable to the house, and the gentlemen
that are bound to keepe theyre vacacions and others, and not fytte to be
continewed hereafter, It is therefore ordered that from henceforth noe
gentleman of this house shalbe chosen or take on him to be liuetenaunt in
the Christmas tyme or by any other name hold that place or keepe any
table as the liutenauntes heretofore haue vsed to doe
. . .

f 638v
. . .
At this Councell yt is ordered that ther shalbe allowed by the house towardes
the Christmas Commons Tenne poundes, and the president of the last yeare
not to be any example to make peticion for any more: for the Reasons sett
downe vppon the allowance thereof
. . .
f 639 (28 [anuary)
. . .
mr Skinner hath paid his ffive poundes accordinge to a former order./
Att this Counsell it is ordered with mr windhams owne assent that he shall
paye ffive poundes to the Treasorer of this howse before the next Counsell./
f 630v
...
Att this Counsell mr Brooke and mr lones two of the Masters of the Bench
ar desired to call the Collectors of the barr, & vnder the barr to an accompt
for such moneyes as they have receved for the Barryars and to appoynt them
to receve such moneyes as is behinde Aswell of those that were in Commons
the last terme As this terme according to the Taxacion./
. . .
f 640* (4 February)
. . .
It is ordered at this Counsell that all such gentlemen of this societye that have
Chambers in the howse or lye in the howse shall pay there Taxacions towardes
the Barriers, And also aswell all such gentlemen that were in Commons the
last terme, As also those which ar or have byn in Commons this terme shall
[like] likewise pay the seuerall sommes of money imposed vpon them, to the
Collectors appoynted for the receipt therof before they goe out of Commons,
And yf the cheif butler permitt any gentleman nowe in Comons to goe out
before he pay the same he shalbe put out of Commons And this order to be
published in the halle./
The order touching the Chusing of a liewtenant in Chrismas is continewed
vntill the next Counsell

4/ president: ie, precedent
5–6/ Reasons sett downe: ie, in the order of 12 February 1615116
34/ he: ie, the butler

Surplusagia
rotulorum

the Bench who is Treasorer for the Barryars./
. . .
The masters of the Bench to be moved to pay to the barriars but howe the
same shalbe levyed is to be considered at the next Counsell.7

. . .
Consideracion is to be had at the first Councell in the next terme whether
the vacacion in the Chrismas tyme shalbe altered & then also to consider of

It is ordered that mr Windham shall pay his V li. before the first Councell in
the next terme peremptorely or ells he is to be putt out of Commons./
It is ordered that such gentlemen of this howse, as shall lye in any benchers
Chambers shall pay ye taxacion layd vppon the benchers in whose chambers
they lye or ells to depart the Chambers vnlesse he be a bencher of this howse./

Petition to Lincoln's Inn MT Arch: MT7[MAA141
single sheet
To the right worshipfull the Masters of the Bench of Lincolnes Inne.
The humble peticion of Thomas Alporte Cittizen and
haberdasher of London
Sheweth that about Ianuary I0 Iacobi Regni Regis your peticioner by the
appointment of Mr Martin of the Middle Temple and Mr Brooke of Lincolnes
Inn did fitt six gentlemen then appointed to be maskers att the Court with
fyne longe white silke hose for the said Maske of the price of SS S. a paire
amountinge in all to 16 li. IOS. for which the said mr Martin and mr Brooke
promised your supliant satisfaccion./
That afterwardes when your supliant demaunded the said money they answered
they had made vpp their accomptes and had noe money lefte [to] in their
handes to paie, And since your supliant hath byn A suitor to the Masters of
the Benche of the Middle Temple and vpon A peticion to them exhibited by

your supliant the matter was by them referred to mr Strowde and mr wotton
two of the Masters of the said Benche to be examyned./
That vpon examynacion they found yt true that the said stockinges were
deliuered by your supliant and that your supliant [was] is yet vnsatisfied
And therefore they haue taken order for your supliantes satisfaccion for
thone moietie beinge viij li. VS. as by the Certificat annexed appeareth.
And for thother moyetie they answered your supliant yt was to be paid by
your worshipps
Maie yt therefore please your worshipps to take order with
master Tresvrer for your supliantes satisfaccion of the said
viij li. VS. fourthwith for that the same hath byn longe due
And your supliant will euer wishe vnto your worshipps all
health and prosperitie./
mr: Brooke did not dele, with mr alport for any stockyns [with mr Martyn]
but bought [6] 6 payre of an other wherwith he furnisht the gentlemen of this
house/ & left mr martyn to provide for those [m] of the myddle temple7*

Petition to the Middle Temple MT Arch: MT7[MAA130
single sheet
To the right worshipfull the Masters of the Benche of the Middle Temple./
The humble peticion of Thomas Alporte Cittizen and
haberdasher of London./
Shewinge That [as] whereas vpon a peticion heretofore exhibited vnto
your worshipps by this peticioner yt pleased your worshipps to referr the
examynacion of your peticioners debte ,of 16 li. 10 s. by him demaunded
(for six paire of silke hose for the maske sold vnto Mr Martin or by his
direction for some of the gentlemen maskers in Ianuary I0: Iacobi Regis.)
[1] vnto Mr lohn Strode & Mr Wotton: who found by the accomptes
themselues, the same was still vnsatisfied And therefore did take order with
Mr Baldwyn undertreasorer for payement of viij li. VS. beinge (the moyetie
thereof) vnto your peticioner. Telling your peticioner That the gentlemen
of Lincolnes Inne were to paie thother moiety as by their certificate
annexed appeareth./
Herevpon your peticioner did likewise peticion vnto the Benchers of Lincolnes
Inne for thother moiety, who haue answred therevnto [that the six pair] that
[the] Mr Brooke did not deale with Mr Alporte, but with another man, &
lefte Mr Martin to prouide for the Middle Temple: which seemeth to be true

20/ silke: S corrected from h
38/ Inne: Icorrected from another letter

for that some of the Maskers of this house haue confessed they had their
stockinges from Mr Alportes man.
Nowe forasmuch as your peticioner is yet vnpaid aswell of
the said viij li. VS. appointed to be paid by Mr Strode &
Mr wotton, as of thother viij li. VS. supposed to be due by
the Masters of Lincolnes Inne. Maye yt therefore please your
worshipps to make your peticioner satisfaccion fourthwith
of the said xvj li. XS. for that he hath byn longe out of his
money. And, he will euer wish vnto your worshipps all
health & prosperity.

Middle Temple Certificate MT Arch: MT7[MAA140
single sheet
Vpon A peticion exhibited vnto the Masters of the Benche of the Middle
Temple by Thomas Alporte of London haberdasher for xvj li. XS. which he
pretendeth to be due vnto him for silke stockinges deliuered vnto gentlemen
of the same Middle Temple and of Lincolnes Inne for the Maske in Ianuary
10 lacobi Regni Regis by the appointment of mr Martin & mr Brooke: The
same peticion was by the [said] Benche referred vnto vs to be examyned: And
vpon examynacion wee finde by perusinge the accomptes deliuered vnto vs
by mr Martin and mr Brooke that the stockinges for which the said Alporte
seeketh satisfaccion weere not paid for by them nor did they in their accomptes
demaund allowance for them: But the said Alporte is yet vnsatisfied: wherefore
wee haue taken order for his satisfaccion (by the Treasurer of the Middle
Temple) of thone moietie of the said xvj li. XS. And thereof alsoe wee [haue]
thought fitt (att the request of mr Alporte) to make Certificate yeoven vnder
our handes the 16th of November 1616
(signed) Iohn Strode (signed) william: wotton:

Sir [ohn Finet, Finetti Philoxenis Wing: F947
pp 73–47
. . .
For Shrove–Tuesday following I carried them from the king an Invitation
to a Maske of the Gentlemen of] the Middle–Temple to be represented
in the Hall of the Court, whether I was appointed to conduct them in one
of the kings Coaches, with order to be in the new Councell Chamber (on
the deceased Oueens side, which had been her Privy Chamber) at seaven
of the Clock without preparation (other then of Bread and Wine for
Collation) I bestowed their followers on a Scaffold on the kings right
hand, and in a Box under (purposely reserved from them) themselves
together with Sir Noell Caron the Ambassador. The Maske ended I brought
them (by direction) to the king, whom they had not yet at that time seen)
whence following his Majesty (without his notice yet taken of them) till
they came to the Guard Chamber, he there saluted them, and had their
attendance to the Banquet there, and after in the Privy Gallery, gave them
all the good night.
. . .

inuitato, sedendo appresso al Re, e riceuendo ogni maggior honore, col
Agente di Fiandra, che pero non hebbe deputato loco. Laltro di alcuni
gentiluomini gioueni, al quale intervennero soli IAmbasciatori dei
Signori Stati: ma posti sopra ad un palco, mentre veramente sono a loro
scarseggiati molto gli honori

Hamon LEstrange, The Reign of Ring Charles: An History Wing: L1180
pp 72–3
. . .
That Christmas the Temple Sparks had enstalled a Lieutenant, a thing
we Country folk call a Lord of Misrule: This Lieutenant had on Twelfth
Eve late in the night sent out to collect his rents in RammeAlley, and
Fleetstreet, limiting five shillings to every house. At every door they winded
their Temple horn, and if it procured not entrance at the second blast or
summons, the word of command was then, Give fire, Gunner. This Gunner
was a robustious Vulcan, and his engine a mighty Smiths hammer. The
next morning the Lord Mayor of London was made acquainted therewith,
and promised to be with them the next night, commanding all that Ward,
and also the Watch to attend him with their Halberds. At the hour prefixt the
Lord Mayor with his train marched up in Martial equipage to Ramme–Alley:
Out came the Lieutenant with his suit of Gallants, all armed in cuerpo. One
of the Halberdiers bad the Lieutenant come to my Lord] Mayor: No, said

Orders
concerning
Christmas/

the Lieutenant, Let the Lord Mayor come to me. But this controversie was
soon ended, they advancing each to other till they met half way, then one
of the Halberdiers reproved the Lieutenant for standing covered before the
Lord Mayor: the Lieutenant gave so crosse an answer, as it begat as crosse a
blow, which the Gentlemen not brooking, began to lay about them: but in
fine, the Lieutenant was knockt down, and sore wounded, and the Halberdiers
had the better of the swords. The Lord Mayor being thus master of the field,
took the Lieutenant, and haled, rather then led him to the Counter, and with
indignation thrust him in at the prison gate, where he lay till the Atturney
General mediated for his enlargement, which the Lord Mayor granted upon
condition he should submit and acknowledge his fault. The Lieutenant
readily embraced the motion, and the next day performing the condition,
so ended this Christmas Game.
. . .

1628–0
Inner Temple Parliament Book IT Arch: PAR1112
f 182* (23 November)
. . .
Whereas by a former order of this Parliament herebefore mencioned, the
Comittees therin named concerning Christmas Commons were to make
theire Reporte to the Table and therevpon such further order was to bee
made as before appeareth
Nowe vpon theire Reporte made these orders are agreed by the Table to bee
enacted as followeth vizt./
That Christmas Commons shall continue by the space of three weekes onlie
and no longer according to the ancient vsage and Custome of this house.
That the Gentlemen who shall bee Treasurers or Stewardes in the tyme of
Christmas shall bee answearable to paye the Baker Brewer Chandler and all
other Officers that shall serve the howse with necessarie provisions during
that tyme./
That no Stranger nor any of this Societie that hathe not bene in the ordinarie
Commons of this howse within two yeares laste paste or standeth as putt extra
per mandatum or ne recipiatur shall bee admitted to take any Repaste or to
bee in Commons in the tyme of Christmas./
That there shall not bee anie drincking of healths during the said tyme of
Christmas Commons nor any wyne brought in or drunck but in the tyme of
meales And then no Vintner or other stranger to attende in the Halle but
onlie the Officers of the howse And that no Tobacco shall bee solde or vttered
within this howse during the said tyme of Christmas./
That no play shall bee continued within the howse after twelve of the Clock
vpon anie Saturday night during the said tyme of three weekes nor after twelve
of the Clock on Christmas Eve att night./

The Inner
Temple.

That there shall not bee anie goeing abroade out of the Circuit of this howse
or without any of the Gates by any Lorde or other Gentleman to breake open
any howse or chamber or to take any thinge in the name of Rent or a distresse.]

Sir William Dugdale, Origines [uridiciales Wing: D2488
p 140 col 2–p150 col 1*
. . .
11. That, for preventing of Cuarrells within the House, and that general
scandal and obloquie which the House hath heretofore incurred in time of
Christmass, there shall no Gentleman of this House, side with any person
whatsoever, that shall offer to disturb the peace and quiet of] the House:
but shall indeavour to punish them, according to the old Custome of the
House: and that no Strangers be suffred to come within the Hall, but such
as shall appear and seem to be of good sort and fashion.
. . .
